content.body: I heard `import defer * as ns` has changed to `import defer ns` is that happening?
content.formatted_body: I heard import defer * as ns has changed to import defer ns is that happening?

content.body: No, where did you read it?
littledan: syntax for meta.resolve() or a different attribute makes a bit more sense to me than overloading `type`
content.formatted_body: littledan: syntax for meta.resolve() or a different attribute makes a bit more sense to me than overloading type

content.body: littledan: at least as currently specified we end up fetching everything with `type` and this `url` thing would create quite the code smell I think
content.formatted_body: littledan: at least as currently specified we end up fetching everything with type and this url thing would create quite the code smell I think

content.body: I don't remember us discussing overloading `type` much in this group. I agree that it's code smell to use that particular attribute. I'd at least use another key
content.formatted_body: I don't remember us discussing overloading type much in this group. I agree that it's code smell to use that particular attribute. I'd at least use another key

content.body: We've mostly discussed syntax like `import asset foo from "./foo.jpeg";` or something
content.formatted_body: We've mostly discussed syntax like import asset foo from "./foo.jpeg"; or something

content.body: Kris didn't like that syntax because he found it ambiguous between whether `foo` was a URL or the bytes
content.formatted_body: Kris didn't like that syntax because he found it ambiguous between whether foo was a URL or the bytes

content.body: even if it's the bytes: we still need the type so that the fetch can be done properly
Is `asset` bytes or URL in that case?
content.formatted_body: Is asset bytes or URL in that case?

content.body: Also, is the underlying Module paused before fetch or after?

I presume that `import bytes from './bin.oct' with { type: 'bytes' }` implies a content-type of `application/octet-stream` and is as such sufficient to go as far as `fetch` especially, especially since there’s no possibility of advancing to evaluation behavior.
content.formatted_body: I presume that import bytes from './bin.oct' with { type: 'bytes' } implies a content-type of application/octet-stream and is as such sufficient to go as far as fetch especially, especially since there’s no possibility of advancing to evaluation behavior.

content.body: I presume also that `import text. from './text.txt' with { type: 'text' }` implies a content-type of `text/plain; charset=utf-8` and is also sufficient to go to `fetch`.
content.formatted_body: I presume also that import text. from './text.txt' with { type: 'text' } implies a content-type of text/plain; charset=utf-8 and is also sufficient to go to fetch.

content.body: Whereas `import url from './image.jpg' with { type: 'url' }` implies nothing about the content-type and wouldn’t advance to `fetch` in any case. Using a different key introduces confusion about the role of `type` in `import asset imageUrl from './image.jpg' with { type: 'jpeg' }` (it would just produce a different memo key)
content.formatted_body: Whereas import url from './image.jpg' with { type: 'url' } implies nothing about the content-type and wouldn’t advance to fetch in any case. Using a different key introduces confusion about the role of type in import asset imageUrl from './image.jpg' with { type: 'jpeg' } (it would just produce a different memo key)

content.body: Or, alternate strawpoke, `type` would be vestigial in `import imageUrl from './image.jpg' with { type: 'jpeg', phase: 'located' }`.
content.formatted_body: Or, alternate strawpoke, type would be vestigial in import imageUrl from './image.jpg' with { type: 'jpeg', phase: 'located' }.

content.body: Kris Kowal: I was thinking we might ignore the `Content-Type` response header for some of these types, as `fetch()` does. Requiring a `Content-Type` like CSS module scripts do would make them not as useful I think.
content.formatted_body: Kris Kowal: I was thinking we might ignore the Content-Type response header for some of these types, as fetch() does. Requiring a Content-Type like CSS module scripts do would make them not as useful I think.
